prior_works.title: A Formal Basis for the Heuristic Determination of Minimum Cost Paths
prior_works.authors: Peter E. Hart, Nils J. Nilsson, Bertram Raphael
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SeeA* builds directly on the A* framework’s OPEN/CLOSED architecture and f=g+h ordering, altering only the node-selection policy within OPEN via selective sampling.

prior_works.title: Heuristic Search Viewed as Path Finding in a Graph
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Weighted A* established that deviating from strict best-f expansion can accelerate search, a principle SeeA* echoes by sometimes bypassing the globally best node to encourage exploration through sampled subsets.

prior_works.title: Bandit Based Monte-Carlo Planning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: SeeA* adapts the MCTS ethos of selective, probabilistically guided sampling to tree search by sampling a subset of OPEN to balance exploitation of good heuristics with exploration of alternatives.

prior_works.title: Mastering the game of Go with deep neural networks and tree search
prior_works.role: Demonstration of heuristic evaluation + MCTS synergy
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The AlphaGo/AlphaZero line showed that combining learned evaluation with exploration-aware tree search yields major gains, motivating SeeA*’s integration of exploration into a heuristic A* backbone.

prior_works.title: Anytime Repairing A* (ARA*): Anytime A* with Provable Bounds
prior_works.authors: Maxim Likhachev, Geoffrey J. Gordon, Sebastian Thrun
prior_works.role: Anytime heuristic search via controlled suboptimality
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ARA*’s success with inflated heuristics underscores the value of occasionally prioritizing nodes other than the strict best-f, informing SeeA*’s strategy of sampled, exploration-permitting selection.

prior_works.title: Beam-Stack Search: Integrating Backtracking with Beam Search
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Beam-style methods restrict attention to a subset of promising frontier nodes, a structural idea SeeA* refines by dynamically sampling a subset of OPEN and expanding the best within it.

prior_works.title: Multi-Heuristic A* (MHA*)
prior_works.role: Exploration via multiple queues/principled deviations from best-f
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MHA*’s practice of sometimes expanding from inadmissible or exploratory queues directly inspires SeeA*’s deliberate departures from the globally best node to improve coverage of promising regions.

synthesis_narrative: SeeA*’s core innovation is to replace A*’s deterministic selection of the globally best OPEN node with a selective sampling scheme: it samples a dynamic subset of OPEN—biased toward good heuristic values—and expands the best node within that subset. This rethinks the node selection stage as an exploration–exploitation problem. The foundation is classical A* (Hart, Nilsson, Raphael), whose OPEN/CLOSED mechanism and f=g+h ordering define the baseline that SeeA* modifies. Early work on intentional suboptimality—Weighted A* (Pohl) and the anytime ARA*—showed that relaxing strict best-f expansion can dramatically improve time-to-first-solution and efficiency; SeeA* adopts a different but related lever, using probabilistic subset selection to occasionally bypass the global best and thus escape heuristic traps. From the MCTS lineage, UCT (Kocsis & Szepesvári) provides the selective sampling mindset: sample and focus on promising choices while preserving exploration, a philosophy directly mirrored in SeeA*’s OPEN-subset sampling. AlphaGo/AlphaZero further validated that combining strong heuristics with exploration-aware tree control yields large practical gains, motivating a revisit of A*’s selection policy. Structurally, beam and beam-stack search (Zhou & Hansen) demonstrated the power of restricting attention to a subset of frontier nodes; SeeA* refines this by sampling rather than deterministically truncating the frontier. Finally, MHA* (Aine & Likhachev) embodies principled deviations from strict best-f via multiple queues, reinforcing the idea that occasional exploration improves robustness—an idea operationalized in SeeA* through selective sampling of OPEN.
